articles.headline: After French Vote, Mainstream Europe Breathes a Sigh of Relief
articles.snippet: Far-right populism has not fully crystallized electorally in Europe, though the issues that have animated the movements are not going anywhere.
articles.abstract: Far-right populism has not fully crystallized electorally in Europe, though the issues that have animated the movements are not going anywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — There was palpable relief in mainstream Europe on Monday at the success of the independent centrist Emmanuel Macron in the first round of the French presidential elections, and a wide assumption that he will defeat the far-right Marine Le Pen in a runoff two weeks from now.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Alison Smale

articles.headline: As North Korea Speeds Its Nuclear Program, U.S. Fears Time Will Run Out
articles.snippet: Behind the Trump administration’s sudden urgency on North Korea lies a stark calculus: that the country is capable of making a nuclear bomb every six or seven weeks.
articles.abstract: Behind the Trump administration’s sudden urgency on North Korea lies a stark calculus: that the country is capable of making a nuclear bomb every six or seven weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Behind the Trump administration’s sudden urgency in dealing with the North Korean nuclear crisis lies a stark calculus: a growing body of expert studies and classified intelligence reports that conclude the country is capable of producing a nuclear bomb every six or seven weeks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Partisan Divide Over Economic Outlook Worries Ben Bernanke
articles.snippet: Republicans think the economy is surging. Democrats think a recession is imminent. When economics become politicized, it leads to bad policy.
articles.abstract: Republicans think the economy is surging. Democrats think a recession is imminent. When economics become politicized, it leads to bad policy.

articles.headline: A Showdown Over Wells Fargo’s Board of Directors Looms
articles.snippet: As the fallout from the sham accounts scandal at Wells Fargo continues, the bank’s directors face a re-election vote by shareholders on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: As the fallout from the sham accounts scandal at Wells Fargo continues, the bank’s directors face a re-election vote by shareholders on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The scandal at Wells Fargo over the creation of millions of fake bank accounts cost more than 5,300 people their jobs, many of them tellers and other low-level employees.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Trump Is Said to Seek Cutting Corporate Tax Rate to 15 Percent
articles.snippet: Such a cut, from the current rate of 35 percent, would mean a significant reduction in revenue that could jettison his campaign promise to curb deficits.
articles.abstract: Such a cut, from the current rate of 35 percent, would mean a significant reduction in revenue that could jettison his campaign promise to curb deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has instructed his advisers to make cutting the corporate tax rate to 15 percent a centerpiece of his tax-cut blueprint to be unveiled this week, according to people with knowledge of his plans, even if that means a significant reduction in revenue that could jettison his campaign promise to curb deficits.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Trump Wants It Known: Grading 100 Days Is ‘Ridiculous’ (but His Were the Best)
articles.snippet: Though he has called it “an artificial barrier” and a “ridiculous standard,” President Trump is deeply anxious that he be judged a success after 100 days.
articles.abstract: Though he has called it “an artificial barrier” and a “ridiculous standard,” President Trump is deeply anxious that he be judged a success after 100 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In case anyone was wondering, President Trump wants it known that he does not care about the false judgment of his administration after just 100 days. “It’s an artificial barrier,” he sniffed the other day. “Not very meaningful,” he scoffed. A “ridiculous standard,” he added on Twitter.

articles.headline: An Activist Investment in Whole Foods Exposes Shifting Power on Wall St.
articles.snippet: In one example of a change in strategy, Neuberger Berman sounded out hedge funds about investing in Whole Foods Market and pressing for change.
articles.abstract: In one example of a change in strategy, Neuberger Berman sounded out hedge funds about investing in Whole Foods Market and pressing for change.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a steward of pension funds and retirement accounts, Neuberger Berman has traditionally employed a staid strategy familiar among big Wall Street money managers: Buy and hold stocks, sit back, and hope for the best.

articles.headline: Debt Crisis Shakes Chinese Town, Pointing to Wider Problems
articles.snippet: Zouping’s troubles show how companies in China guarantee one another’s loans, representing a potential hazard within China’s vast financial system.
articles.abstract: Zouping’s troubles show how companies in China guarantee one another’s loans, representing a potential hazard within China’s vast financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — In China, it’s all about whom you owe.
